intro: Campanula damboldtiana, commonly known as the Damboldt bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue to violet flowers that bloom in summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy, lance-shaped leaves that are arranged alternately along the stem. It prefers well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade, often found in rocky or alpine habitats. Its ornamental value makes it a sought-after plant in botanical gardens and specialized horticulture.
